questions.text: The ECG of a patient with core body temperature of 85 °F is shown below. What is the hallmark of this patient's ECG, marked by arrows in the image below?
questions.solution:
The hallmark of this patient's ECG is the Osborn J wave.

Hypothermia is defined as core body temperature being less than 95°F and is associated with ECG changes such as: 

  • In the initial stages of hypothermia, as a reaction to the general stress, there is sinus tachycardia.
  • As the temperature drops below 90°F there is sinus bradycardia associated with prolongation of the PR interval, QRS complex, and QT interval progressively.
  • With temperature approaching 86°F, atrial ectopic activity is often noted and can progress to atrial fibrillation. It is at this level of hypothermia that many patients have Osborn waves that consist of an extra deflection at the end of the QRS complex. J waves occur when a heterogeneous distribution of potassium current enhances the activity of a transient outward potassium current in the heart, caused by low temperatures.

Osborn waves, also known as J waves, camel-hump waves or hypothermic waves, are best seen the inferior and lateral precordial leads. They become more prominent as the body temperature drops, and they regress gradually with rewarming.

A progressive widening of the QRS complex occurs when the temperature falls below 86°F, which is associated with an increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and asystole occurs when the temperature drops to ≈60°F

Other options:

Option A: Prominent U waves are seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Tall peaked T waves are the first change in the ECG as the plasma potassium level rises.

Option C: ST segment elevation is seen in Myocardial infarction.

questions.text: An 85-year-old female presented with acute-onset palpitations for the last 3 days. She is a diabetic since her childhood and has had multiple episodes of hospitalization in the past. Her ECG is given below. There was evidence of thrombus in the left atria on transesophageal electrocardiography. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent 'p' waves, which is consistent with atrial fibrillation. An episode that lasted for more than 48hours carries a high risk of thromboembolism.

Anticoagulation is initiated and ideally recommended for 4 weeks. However, the duration needs to be reduced in this elderly female who is a diabetic and has a long history of hospitalization. To reduce the duration of pre-cardioversion anticoagulation, Transesophageal electrocardiography (TEE) is indicated to screen for any thrombus in the left atria. TEE is not mandatory in all patients, it is only helpful if early cardioversion has to be planned.

  • If the absence of a thrombus is ensured, cardioversion may be carried out safely. However, Anticoagulation is recommended for a minimum of 4weeks post-conversion in ALL the patients.
  • If the presence of thrombus is confirmed, anticoagulation has to be carried out for another 4weeks. After these 4weeks, Transesophageal electrocardiography is used to rule out the evidence of thrombus.

 

In general, all patients with all types of Atrial Fibrillation carry an increased risk of thromboembolism. This risk is furthermore increased transiently when sinus rhythm is restored either intendedly or spontaneously. During or two weeks after cardioversion, the most common source of stroke in these patients is the embolism of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. The major causes are:

  • embolism from a pre-formed thrombus.
  • embolism from thrombus formed post-conversion worsening of atrial function.
  • embolism from subsequent episodes of AF.

 

  Risk of thromboembolism present 'before' reverting to normal sinus rhythm. Risk of thromboembolism 'during' reverting to normal sinus rhythm. Risk of thromboembolism 'after' reverting to normal sinus rhythm.
The source of thromboembolism.  The thrombus that is already pre-formed in the left atria might get dislodged during cardioversion. There is an incremental increase in the risk at the time of reversion to normal sinus rhythm. Most of the embolic events occur within 10 days of reversion. The mechanical/contractile dysfunction of atria is called atrial 'stunning'. It creates a milieu for de novo synthesis of thrombus in the atria.

The high-risk patients.

The prevalence is increased in high-risk patients having:

  • severe LV systolic dysfunction
  • left atrial enlargement
  • depressed left atrial appendage ejection velocity
  • left atrial appendage spontaneous echo contrast(a marker of stasis)

The particularly high-risk patients are those who had an episode of AF longer than 48 hours or unknown duration.

 

The prevalence of left atrial appendage on transesophageal echocardiography is significantly lower when the duration is less than 48 hours.

 

Recurrent episodes of AF are also common in the first-month post-conversion.

Control the risk of thromboembolism with Anticoagulation.

Anticoagulation is recommended for a minimum of 3weeks pre-conversion if the CHA2DS2-VASc score of a patient is >=1. DOAC are preferred to Warfarin, if not contra-indicated.

The loading dose of IV Heparin is instituted prior to urgent cardioversion if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

 Anticoagulation is recommended for a minimum of 4weeks post-conversion in ALL the patients.

The duration of atrial fibrillation - those who present within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms have a lower risk of an existing atrial thrombus and can be safely cardioverted. Those who present with unknown or known onset of more than 48 hours should ideally be anticoagulated 3 weeks before cardioversion. However, a hemodynamically unstable patient must be immediately cardioverted. Cardioversion has to be followed by 4 weeks of anticoagulation in all the patients.

Anticoagulation is recommended for a minimum of 4weeks post-conversion in ALL the patients.

An episode of AF lasting more than 48 hours. (Flowchart)

questions.text: Identify the tachycardia depicted in the given ECG.
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves (red arrows), known as flutter waves. Hence, it is most likely to be atrial flutter.

In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. As the atrial rate is around 300 bpm, AV conduction ratio of 2:1 results in a ventricular rate of ~150 bpm.

Other options :

Option a : Atrial fibrillation rhythm is irregularly irregular. P waves are absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, characteristic of atrial fibrillation, as shown in the ECG below.

Option c : Ventricular tachycardia ecg changes include wide QRS complexes, absence of P waves, and ventriculoatrial dissociation. In monomorphic VT, all QRS complexes look the same. Polymorphic VT has QRS complexes varying in shape or direction in the same lead.

The ecg of ventricular tachycardia is given below.

Option d : Ventricular fibrillation shows a completely disorganized rhythm with no identifiable waves on ECG, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male has made frequent visits to the emergency room for management of atrial flutter. The consultant administers a drug that shows the following effect. What is the likely drug administered?
questions.solution:
For recurrent episodes of atrial flutter, antiarrhythmic drugs such as sotalol, dofetilide, disopyramide, and amiodarone may be prescribed. These drugs belong to class 1A (disopyramide) and 3 (sotalol and dofetilide) and cause torsades de pointes as shown in the image.

Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia meaning “twisting of the points,” characterized by twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance. Torsade rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia. There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization. 

Causes of torsades de pointes include:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide, and phenothiazine (amiodarone is rarely associated with torsades de pointes because the delay in repolarization induced by it is uniform).
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice in Torsades de pointes and not a causative drug.

 

Management of Atrial flutter:

  • The initial management of atrial flutter depends on the patient’s condition and symptoms.
  • If the patient has severe hypotension, angina, or is haemodynamically unstable, then the first step is to perform electrical cardioversion.
  • If the patient’s condition is stable, then the initial step is to achieve rate-control by administration of AV nodal–blocking agents, such as IV beta-blockers.
  • If the duration of the episode is > 48 hrs, or if the patient has an increased risk of thromboembolic stroke based on the CHADS -VASc scoring system then anticoagulation must be provided prior to the cardioversion.
  • For recurrent episodes, antiarrhythmic drugs such as sotalol, dofetilide, disopyramide, and amiodarone may be prescribed.

questions.text: An ECG as shown below is given to you. What AV Ratio is most commonly seen in this arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
The given ECG showing regular rhythm, the rate between 250-300 bpm, and normal P waves being replaced by saw tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves is diagnostic of atrial flutter and the commonest AV ratio is a 2:1 ratio.

In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. In the above ECG, the rhythm is atrial flutter 4:1 block with an atrial rate of about 270 and a ventricular rate of 68/min.

It is extremely difficult to distinguish between atrial tachycardia with a block, from atrial flutter especially in a 2:1 block since the flutter waves may not be appreciated and may be appreciated only after attempts at exposing the AV block are made.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block
  4. Complete heart block
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-B, 2-D,3-A,4-C.

The different types of heart blocks are:

1.First Degree Heart Block: Prolonged PR > 0.2s, RR interval equal

2. Second Degree Heart Block:  missed QRS

  • Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach: Progressive prolongation of PR interval, missed QRS
  • Mobitz type 2: fixed PR interval, missed QRS

3. Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

Related Pearl: Heart Blocks

Type

Pathology

ECG features

First-degree block

All atrial impulses are conducted to ventricles  but there is a delay

PR interval is constant and >0.2 sec

Second-degree block

not all atrial impulses are conducted to the ventricles

Atrial P waves present but no QRST wave (dropped ventricular beats)

Third-degree block (complete heart block)

Complete blockage of impulses from atria to ventricles

Dissociation between P wave and QRS complexes

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex - upto 0.10s

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval - 0.12 -0.2s 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QRS duration

Ventricular depolarization

QT interval - upto 0.43s

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: Diagnose the ECG and choose the false statement about the condition?

choices.text: Most common symptom of pulmonary embolism is dyspnea
Most common sign of pulmonary embolism is tachycardia
Most common ECG abnormality in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia
Most common investigation used is ECG.

questions.solution:
Most common sign of pulmonary embolism is tachypnea.

  • Most common symptom of pulmonary embolism is dyspnea.
  • Most common ECG abnormality in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia.
  • Most common preventable cause of death in the hospitalised patients is Pulmonary embolism.
  • S1Q3T3 sign,on ECG (i.e, an S wave in lead I, a Q wave in lead III, and an inverted T wave in lead III) is relatively specific but insensitive.
  • Most common preliminary investigation used is D Dimer.

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting.  On examination, his pulse rate is 58 per minute and blood pressure is 90/60 mm of Hg. ECG was done and it shows the following finding. Cardiac biomarker showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of chest pain, and elevated biomarkers depict that the patient has a myocardial infarction. In the ECG, there is elevation of ST-segments in leads II, III, aVF, with reciprocal change in lead aVL. This depicts inferior wall MI. It mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery.

The table below gives localization of MI and probable vessel involved based on ECG findings.

Location of MI Leads Affected Vessel Involved ECG Changes
Anterior wall V2 to V4 Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD)
– Diagonal branch
  • Poor R-wave progression
  • ST-segment elevation
  • T-wave inversion
Septal wall V1 and V2 Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD)
– Septal branch
  • R-wave disappears
  • ST-segment rises
  • T-wave inverts
Lateral wall I, aVL, V5, V6 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch
  • ST-segment elevation
Inferior wall II, III, aVF Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch
  • T-wave inversion
  • ST-segment elevation
Posterior wall V7 to V9 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch

 

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch
  • Tall R waves
  • ST-segment depression
  • Upright T waves

Patients with pericarditis also present with severe chest pain and ST-segment elevations. However, this ST-segment elevation has upward concavity with depression of PR segment.

Below image- ECG in pericarditis

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. He has a history of inferior-wall myocardial infarction a year ago. Holter study was done and his 24 hour  ECG strip obtained is given below. What is the long-term treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on his ECG findings, this patient is suffering from symptomatic (palpitations, syncope) Mobitz Type II AV block. The definitive long-term treatment is, therefore, a permanent pacemaker. 

Mobitz Type II AV block is characterized by:

  • a constant PR interval
  • some P waves not be followed by QRS complexes

According to the rhythm strip (Lead II) of the ECG shown, the patient is experiencing a 3:2 AV block which is then progressing to a 2:1 AV block.

This patient is also suffering from a right bundle branch block (RBBB) as indicated by the wide QRS complexes in leads V1, V2, and V3 ('M'-shaped). 

This patient with a history of ischemic heart disease (previous history of inferior-wall MI) and objective signs of Mobitz Type II AV block and RBBB will benefit most from a permanent pacemaker. 

In the ECG below, the blue arrows show some P waves that were not followed by QRS complexes. The missed QRS complex is pointed by the red arrow. The red box indicates the wide QRS complexes in leads V1, V2, and V3:

 

Other options:

Option A - Amiodarone, a class III anti-arrhythmic agent, is the drug of choice in the acute treatment as well as prevention of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. It is a rate-control medication. 

Options B and D - Pharmacologic interventions such as atropine and isoproterenol serve as short-term supplementary treatment options until a pacemaker can be installed or if the AV block is transient in nature. Even in such instances, a temporary transcutaneous pacemaker is preferred until a permanent device is available. 

Related Pearl: Indication for Pacemaker in AV Conduction Defects

  • In any patient with symptomatic bradycardia
  • Irreversible second- or third-degree AV bloc
  • Pacing in patients with asymptomatic AV block should be individualized

With acquired CHB

Left ventricular dysfunction and

Waking heart rates 40 beats/min.
  • Asymptomatic second-degree AV block of either type, if the block is demonstrated to be intra- or infra-His or is associated with a wide QRS complex
  • Neuromuscular diseases having a predilection for the conduction system, such as myotonic dystrophy and other muscular dystrophies, and Kearns-Sayre syndrome

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A 60-year old hypertensive male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with acute onset palpitations. He has a past history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. He often complains of fatiguability and intolerance to exercise on most days. On further inquiry, attendants revealed that the patient has been experiencing progressively irregular loss of memory, and that he was non-compliant with his medications for hypertension and hyperthyroidism. Which of the following ECG most likely belongs to the patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent 'p' waves, which is consistent with atrial fibrillation.


The patient with mitral stenosis presenting with acute onset palpitations, along with the history of multiple episodes of TIA is most likely to have had an episode of Atrial Fibrillation. Mitral stenosis is well known to cause atrial fibrillation being a common cause of cardioembolic stroke. Hypertension is a major risk factor. Also, Hyperthyroidism should be considered in elderly patients with atrial fibrillation and unexplained heart failure. AF might have been precipitated by non-compliance with the medications along with the two risk factors mentioned.

Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina, or cochlea. Most TIAs last for less than 1 hour to a few minutes. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA.

The attendants also revealed dementia which is PROGRESSIVE and IRREGULAR. In the background of TIA episodes, dementia corresponds to vascular origin. Vascular dementia is commonly seen in the setting of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, Peripheral Vascular Disease, and diabetes. In patients suffering from CerebroVascularDisease, it's difficult to determine whether dementia is due to Alzheimer’s Disease, Vascular or both. 

CLINICAL PATTERN OF LOSS OF MEMORY ORIGIN OF DEMENTIA
  1. Irregular progression with h/o stroke
  1. Vascular Dementia  
  1. Acute/ Subacute - DELIRIUM
  1. Infection/ Intoxication/ Metabolic. Eg Hypokalemia or Hyperkalemia
  1. Very slow progression in elderly
  1. AD (Alzheimer's Disease)
  1. Personality change, disinhibition, weight gain, compulsive eating
  1. FTD  (FrontoTemporal Dementia)
  1. Early visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, delirium
  1. DLB (Dementia with Lewy Bodies)
  1. Rapid progression + motor rigidity
  1. CJD (Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease)
  1. Recurrent head trauma 
  1. Chronic Subdural Hematoma

 

Option A: The ECG in A depicts tall, peaked T waves with a narrow base, short QT interval; and ST-segment depression., widened QRS complex. The features are consistent with the findings of Hyperkalemia.


Option C: The ECG depicts characteristic pattern of Hypokalemia. 
Metabolic abnormalities like hyperkalemia or hypokalemia are typically associated with delirium presenting with an acute/subacute onset. 


Option D: Sinus rhythm is unlikely as the patient with mitral stenosis has presented with palpitations.


For further management, it is mandatory to calculate the CHA2DS2 Vasc SCORE in order to predict the future risk of stroke, and the use of antithrombotics is based on the CHADS2 score.

questions.text: A 32-year-old diabetic man was undergoing a routine check-up. ECG revealed ST changes as given below. Repeated cardiac biomarkers were found to be within the normal range. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows coved ST-segment elevation of V1-V3 followed by a negative T wave (Brugada sign) which points to a diagnosis of Brugada syndrome. A coved ST-segment has a downward concavity.

Brugada syndrome is an inherited sodium channelopathy (SCN5A mutation) and is most commonly seen in Southeast Asian males. The age of presentation is usually 40 years. This syndrome is characterized by an increased risk for sudden cardiac death due to polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is the treatment of choice.

Other options -

Options B, C, and D - 

To establish a diagnosis of ST-elevation MI and NSTEMI, a positive and significant rise in cardiac biomarkers (troponins) is necessary along with one of the following features:

  • Symptoms of ischemia
  • New ST-T elevation or LBBB (not for NSTEMI)
  • Pathologic Q waves (STEMI, old infarcts)
  • Imaging evidence of loss of myocardium viability
  • Intracoronary thrombus identified on angioplasty or autopsy

Since we do not have a typical rise and fall pattern of cardiac biomarkers, in this case, a diagnosis of acute ST-elevation MI and NSTEMI are less likely.

Causes of ST-T changes apart from acute MI:

  • Acute pericarditis (Diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and PR depression)
  • Brugada patterns (right bundle branch block-like pattern with ST elevations in right precordial leads) seen secondary to electrolyte disturbances like hyperkalemia.
  • Hyperkalemia (peaked T waves)

questions.text: The ECG given below shows:

choices.text: A prolonged PR interval measuring 240 ms
A normal PR interval measuring 240 ms
A prolonged PR interval measuring 160 ms
A normal PR interval measuring 160 ms

questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a prolonged PR interval measuring 240 msec.

The given ECG shows a PR interval measuring 6 small boxes. One small box represents 0.04 sec. Therefore, 6 boxes is 6*0.04 sec = 0.240 sec or 240 msec. 

The PR interval is measured from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. The normal PR interval is 120-200ms.

The image below represents the PR interval:

 

A prolonged PR interval occurs due to a delay in the conduction of electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles. It is also termed a first-degree heart (AV) block. It is important to note that there is no interruption in conduction. 

People with first-degree AV block are generally asymptomatic and do not require any intervention.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the mechanism behind this condition?

choices.text: Automaticity of multiple foci in the atrium
Macro re-entry circuit in the right atrium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different p wave morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT). The mechanism triggering multifocal atrial tachycardia is the automaticity of multiple atrial foci.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals, hence it can be atrial fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image). Whereas, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.

 

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness.  

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate > 100, typically between 100 and 150 beats/min
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Narrow QRS complex
  • Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies 
  • Variable PR interval

Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. The calcium channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem are useful in slowing the atrial and ventricular rates. Radiofrequency ablation of the AV node is another treatment modality. Cardioversion is ineffective. 

Other options:

Option A - Increased atrial automaticity is seen in atrial tachycardia which is a narrow-complex tachycardia where abnormal P-wave morphology is observed. It can lead to an AV block if the rate is too rapid.

Option C - Atrial flutter is characterized by a macro re-entry circuit in the right atrium which is usually encircling the tricuspid annulus. ECG shows characteristic saw-tooth flutter waves.

Option D - Abnormal bands of conductive tissue between the atria and ventricles are seen in atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia. ECG shows a characteristic delta wave in the presence of these accessory pathways.

questions.text: Tall and tented T waves, wide QRS, and absent P wave are features of:
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia produces a sequence of changes usually beginning with narrowing and peaking (tenting) of the T waves. Further elevation of extracellular K+ leads to:

  • AV conduction disturbances.
  • Diminution in P-wave amplitude.
  • Widening of the QRS interval.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5 - 6.5 mEq/L tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5 - 7.5 mEq/L loss of P waves
3 7.0 - 8.0 mEq/L widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L sine wave

 Severe hyperkalemia eventually causes cardiac arrest with a slow sinusoidal type of mechanism("sine-wave" pattern) followed by asystole.

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, potassium-sparing diuretics. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text: A patient who was being treated for an arrhythmia presented with palpitations and chest discomfort. His ECG has been given below. Which of the following drugs would be least likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient shows wide QRS complexes and an undulating baseline suggesting the diagnosis of torsades de pointed. It is associated with prolonged QT interval. Lidocaine use does not prolong the QT interval, hence, it is unlikely to cause torsades de pointes. 

Lidocaine belongs to the class IB antiarrhythmic agent. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenic potential among antiarrhythmic.QT interval is usually unaltered or slightly reduced with lidocaine use.

Among the antiarrhythmics, class Ia and class III drugs prolong action potential duration and thus prolong QT interval and are also prone to cause Torsades de pointes.

 

Management - Torsade de Pointes is a non-sustained tachycardia that usually resolves on its own. However, premature beats and non-sustained episodes may precede sustained episodes. It may worsen to cause ventricular fibrillation.

  • If the tachycardia is stable, IV MgSO4, 1-2g over 5-60 minutes, followed by an infusion, is highly effective for both treatment and prevention, of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes. 
  • Discontinue the offending drug and correct electrolyte abnormalities. 
  • If this condition progresses into ventricular fibrillation, the appropriate course of action is to perform defibrillation.

questions.text: Identify the rhythm in the following ECG rhythm strip.
questions.solution:
The above ECG strip shows normal sinus rhythm.

The features in this ECG that suggest this diagnosis are as follows:

  • The QRS complexes are narrow (<120 ms or 3 small squares) which implies that the impulse is supraventricular and is conducted via the normal conduction pathway.

 

  • Each QRS complex is preceded by a P wave. This means that all the atrial depolarizations that arise in the sinus node are conducted to the ventricles.

 

  • The PR interval is constant for all the impulses and is normal(<200 ms) in duration.

 

  • The RR interval is constant which implies a regular rhythm.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient is assessed with an ECG during his wellness check-up visit. Calculate the heart rate from the ECG given below.
questions.solution:
The RR interval has 19 small boxes in between, and hence the heart rate is 1500/19~79/min.

The relationship between the heart rate and the RR interval is given by: 

Heart rate = 1500/(number of small boxes (1mm each) in between successive R waves) 

Methods to calculate heart rate from ECG: 

Box counting methods: This can be done via the number of small boxes or the large boxes between two successive R waves. If using the large boxes, the equation is  

Heart rate = 300/(number of big boxes (5mm each) in between successive R waves) 

QRS counting methods: This is used when the heart rate is irregular. Thus there will be a variability in the RR intervals, making the box-counting method unreliable. Here, the number of QRS intervals in a set interval, for example, 10 seconds, is counted. This number is then multiplied by an appropriate factor to get an estimate for 60s. In this example, we would multiple the number of QRS complexes in 10s by 6. 

Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of more than 100 beats/minute and bradycardia is defined as a heart rate of less than 60 beats/minute.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency with chest discomfort following a football match. His ECG is as below. Which of the following is an accurate description of the ECG finding?
questions.solution:
The given ECG depicts De Winter’s T waves. There is no ST elevation in V2, but there is a hyperacute T-wave.  This is a De Winter's T-wave and diagnostic of near occlusion of the LAD.  V3 also has ST depression with a hyperacute T-wave very suggestive of de Winter's T-waves.

  • The de Winter ECG pattern is an anterior STEMI equivalent that presents without obvious ST-segment elevation.

Diagnostic Criteria

  • Tall, prominent, symmetric T waves in the precordial leads
  • Upsloping ST-segment depression >1mm at the J-point in the precordial leads
  • Absence of ST elevation in the precordial leads
  • ST segment elevation (0.5mm-1mm) in aVR

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. The ECG depicts ________.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex: QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

 MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves: late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

 

RBBB

LBBB

questions.text: The following ECG  depicts ?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy.

ECG findings suggestive of RVH:

  • R-V1 >= 7mm
  • R-V1 + S-V5/V6 > 11mm
  • Right axis deviation of +110° or more
  • T wave inversion in RV leads (Lead III, V1 & V2)

Causes of RVH

  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Mitral stenosis
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Chronic lung disease (Cor pulmonale)
  • Congenital heart disease (e.g. Tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary stenosis)
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy

Other options:

1)The ECG depicts ventricular bigeminy seen in Premature Ventricular Complexes.

2)The ECG shows a right bundle branch block.

ECG findings suggestive of RBBB

  • RSR’ pattern in V1-3 (‘M-shaped’ QRS complex)
  • Wide, slurred S wave in the lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-6)
  • T wave inversion in the RV leads
  • Broad QRS > 120 ms

3)The ECG is of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as it shows narrow QRS complexes without visible p waves and pseudo R' waves in aVR lead.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the ER with dizziness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, pulse rate is 45/minute. Her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shown above is the second-degree atrioventricular block type 1 - Wenckebach phenomenon.

Treatment is indicated when bradycardia is accompanied by any one of the following:

  • Hypotension
  • Acutely altered mental status
  • Signs of shock
  • Ischemic chest discomfort
  • Acute heart failure

Treatment is initiated with 1 mg atropine iv which may be repeated at 3-5 minute intervals to a maximum dose of 3 mg.

Along with atropine, transcutaneous pacing is to be done.

If the bradycardia is refractory to both atropine and transcutaneous pacing, then IV infusions of dopamine (5 to 20 μg/kg/min) or epinephrine (2 to 10 μg/min) should be considered.

If the patient still isn’t responding, then transvenous pacing should be tried. If the patient is under spinal anesthesia, low-dose (0.2 mg) IV epinephrine can be given.

Epinephrine is the drug of choice for treating bradyarrhythmias in infants and children.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man was brought to the casualty with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate was 160/min and blood pressure was 110/80 mm Hg. His ECG is given below. What is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient has paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. As the patient's blood pressure is normal and there is no evidence of hemodynamic deterioration, initial treatment consists of vagal maneuvers (Valsalva maneuver) in awake patients. This is because vagal maneuvers alone can terminate approximately 20% to 25% of reentry supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs).

If this is unsuccessful, then IV adenosine 6 mg is given. If necessary another dose of adenosine 12 mg may be administered after 1-2 minutes.

If the drug is administered via a central venous catheter, then these doses are reduced to 3 mg and 6 mg, respectively.

If there is hemodynamic deterioration, then cardioversion is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: The AH interval on His Bundle Electrocardiogram (HBE) corresponds to the conduction of _____ on ECG.

choices.text: From AV node to bundle of His

questions.solution:
The AH interval corresponds to conduction from AV node to bundle of His on an ECG.

His bundle electrogram (HBE)

The record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve is HBE.

It shows 3 deflections as shown in the figure:

 

His bundle waves

Description

A

Denotes AV node activation

H

Denotes His bundle activation

V

Denotes ventricular depolarization 

 

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately

 

Interval

Recording

Corresponding event

PA interval

Time from the first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE

Conduction time from SA node to AV node

AH interval

From A wave to start of H spike

AV nodal conduction time

HV interval

Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG

Conduction in Bundle of His and bundle branches

questions.text: Which lead does the given ECG tracing represent in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus.

Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead produces a negative deflection in the ECG.

The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart.

questions.text: A patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed a narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160 BPM. His blood pressure is 96/68 mmHg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Narrow complex tachycardia without visible P waves and sudden onset palpitations suggest AV node reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). It is a type of PSVT. Carotid sinus massage (or any other vagal maneuver) will be the best next step in management as vagal maneuvers can terminate an approximate 10-20% of AVNRT’s.

The patient is clinically stable (SBP > 90 mm Hg), hence there is no need for defibrillation.

The drug of choice would still be adenosine > beta-blockers which can be used in cases of failed vagal maneuvers.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (shown in the image below)

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:

  • 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: Sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are seen in

choices.text: Recording done with paper speed of 12.5 mm/s
Recording done with paper speed of 50 mm/s

questions.solution:
Sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are seen in a patient that is not relaxed. 

Though the ECG recorders are configured to pick up the electrical frequency generated by the heart better, they also detect the contractions of skeletal muscles. So, unless the patient is relaxed and lying down comfortably, the tracing may show some skeletal muscle activity.

Ex:- 

A patient that is shivering due to cold, or one that has involuntary movements due to conditions like Parkinson's, etc would cause spikes in the baseline of the ECG.

In the case of shivering, the spikes would be more exaggerated and synchronized than that seen in a patient that is not adequately relaxed, because of the skeletal muscle groups contracting together in case of shivering.

 

Other options:

  • Patients with hypothyroidism would show bradycardia, low voltage QRS complexes, and widespread T-wave inversions.
  • The recording is normally done with a paper speed of 25 mm/s.
    • Recording at 12.5 mm/s, which is slower than normal, would cause QRS complex that are close together (creating the false impression of a rapid heart rate) and P waves, QRS complexes, and T waves that are narrow and spiky
    • Recording at 50 mm/s, which is faster than normal, would produce longer intervals between QRS complexes (creating the false impression of a slow heart rate), widened QRS complexes, and an apparently long QT interval.

questions.text: A patient with dizziness and breathing difficulty came to the emergency department. The ECG is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms suggests a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion. 

Other options:

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. There is widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment.

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by a progressive fibrotic change in the pericardium that causes it to thicken and calcify. This leads to impaired cardiac contraction and filling. This gives rise to fatigue, elevated JVP (rapid y descent), ascites, and pulsus paradoxus. ECG findings in constrictive pericarditis consist of non-specific T-wave abnormalities. 

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction of a non-dilated ventricle with, mildly decreased contractility and ejection fraction. It often present with right-sided heart symptoms like edema, ascites, and abdominal discomfort. A fourth heart sound is predominately heard than a third heart sound and is often associated with atrial fibrillation. JVP shows rapid y descent and may increase with inspiration. Kussmaul's sign is an indication of restrictive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: What is the possible diagnosis for a patient with the ECG findings as shown below?
questions.solution:
The ECG image give shows diffuse ST-segment elevation characteristic of acute pericarditis.

Other options:

  • Inferior wall MI will show ST elevations in leads II, III, aVF
  • The ECG findings for pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade are:
    • Sinus tachycardia
    • Electrical alternans
    • Low QRS voltages
  • The ECG changes of hypothyroidism will include bradycardia with low voltage complexes.

questions.text: The ECG wave as shown in the image below is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
The above ECG wave characteristically depicts Digoxin effect.

Digoxin effect refers to the presence on the ECG of:

  • Downsloping ST depression with a characteristic “Salvador Dali sagging” or “Hockey Stick” appearance.
  • Flattened, inverted, or biphasic T waves.
  • Shortened QT interval.

Additional ECG Features:

  • Mild PR interval prolongation of up to 240ms (due to increased vagal tone).
  • Prominent U waves.
  • Peaking of the terminal portion of the T waves.
  • J point depression (usually in leads with tall R waves).

QRS complex / ST segment changes:

  • The morphology of the QRS complex / ST segment is variously described as either “slurred”, “sagging” or “scooped” and resembling either a “reverse tick”, “hockey stick” or “Salvador Dali’s moustache”.
